page.title: 07Tamar Valley
page.content: the river Tamar meanders north to south in this section, its line forming the Devon/Cornwall boundary No bridges or ferries at this point, the river is a social divide. No flooding here. The banks, tree lined on both sides in some stretches, give timeless beauty and unspoilt habitat for plants and animals. Private fishing yields salmon, eel, grayling, and brown trout. Fishermen observe kingfisher, dipper, heron, mallard, green woodpecker, grey wagtail, swallow, sand martin and otters. Woodland animals; tawny,owl,woodcock, buzzard, jay, pheasant, red deer, badger, mole, mink, hares, rabbits & foxes. Sparse human occupation. Isolated farming families self-sufficient with yard animals. The fertile land supports beef primarily, 2 dairy farms only. Many sheep due to EEC subsidies.
